segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Add workstations to domain security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Add workstations to domain security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Add workstations to domain security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Add workstations to domain security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users can add a device to a specific domain.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users can add a device to a specific domain.

segment.source: For it to take effect, it must be assigned so that it applies to at least one domain controller.
segment.target: For it to take effect, it must be assigned so that it applies to at least one domain controller.

segment.source: A user who is assigned this user right can add up to ten workstations to the domain.
segment.target: A user who is assigned this user right can add up to ten workstations to the domain.

segment.source: Adding a machine account to the domain allows the device to participate in Active Directory-based networking.
segment.target: Adding a machine account to the domain allows the device to participate in Active Directory-based networking.

segment.source: Configure this setting so that only authorized members of the IT team are allowed to add devices to the domain.
segment.target: Configure this setting so that only authorized members of the IT team are allowed to add devices to the domain.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default, this setting allows access for Authenticated Users on domain controllers, and it is not defined on stand-alone servers.
segment.target: By default, this setting allows access for Authenticated Users on domain controllers, and it is not defined on stand-alone servers.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: Users can also join a computer to a domain if they have the Create Computer Objects permission for an organizational unit (OU) or for the Computers container in the directory.
segment.target: Users can also join a computer to a domain if they have the Create Computer Objects permission for an organizational unit (OU) or for the Computers container in the directory.

segment.source: Users who are assigned this permission can add an unlimited number of devices to the domain regardless of whether they have the Add workstations to domain user right.
segment.target: Users who are assigned this permission can add an unlimited number of devices to the domain regardless of whether they have the Add workstations to domain user right.

segment.source: Furthermore, machine accounts that are created by means of the Add workstations to domain user right have Domain Administrators as the owner of the machine account.
segment.target: Furthermore, machine accounts that are created by means of the Add workstations to domain user right have Domain Administrators as the owner of the machine account.

segment.source: Machine accounts that are created by means of permissions on the computer’s container use the creator as the owner of the machine account.
segment.target: Machine accounts that are created by means of permissions on the computer’s container use the creator as the owner of the machine account.

segment.source: If a user has permissions on the container and also has the Add workstation to domain user right, the device is added based on the computer container permissions rather than the user right.
segment.target: If a user has permissions on the container and also has the Add workstation to domain user right, the device is added based on the computer container permissions rather than the user right.

segment.source: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This policy has the following security considerations:
segment.target: This policy has the following security considerations:

segment.source: The Add workstations to domain user right presents a moderate vulnerability.
segment.target: The Add workstations to domain user right presents a moderate vulnerability.

segment.source: Users with this right could add a device to the domain that is configured in a way that violates organizational security policies.
segment.target: Users with this right could add a device to the domain that is configured in a way that violates organizational security policies.

segment.source: For example, if your organization does not want its users to have administrative privileges on their devices, users could install Windows on their computers and then add the computers to the domain.
segment.target: For example, if your organization does not want its users to have administrative privileges on their devices, users could install Windows on their computers and then add the computers to the domain.

segment.source: The user would know the password for the local administrator account, could log on with that account, and then add a personal domain account to the local Administrators group.
segment.target: The user would know the password for the local administrator account, could log on with that account, and then add a personal domain account to the local Administrators group.

segment.source: Configure this setting so that only authorized members of the IT team are allowed to add computers to the domain.
segment.target: Configure this setting so that only authorized members of the IT team are allowed to add computers to the domain.

segment.source: For organizations that have never allowed users to set up their own computers and add them to the domain, this countermeasure has no impact.
segment.target: For organizations that have never allowed users to set up their own computers and add them to the domain, this countermeasure has no impact.

segment.source: For those that have allowed some or all users to configure their own devices, this countermeasure forces the organization to establish a formal process for these procedures going forward.
segment.target: For those that have allowed some or all users to configure their own devices, this countermeasure forces the organization to establish a formal process for these procedures going forward.

segment.source: It does not affect existing computers unless they are removed from and then added to the domain.
segment.target: It does not affect existing computers unless they are removed from and then added to the domain.
